validation_metadata.verification_method: Direct review of Alaska Statutes Title 40, Chapter 25 and Alaska Administrative Code 2 AAC 96

rights_of_access.description: Except as otherwise prohibited by law, all public records are open to inspection by the public. This establishes Alaska's foundational presumption of public access to government records.
rights_of_access.conditions: Inspection at reasonable times, under reasonable conditions, with supervision by custodian; applies unless specifically prohibited by law
rights_of_access.applies_to: All public records held by Alaska state agencies and political subdivisions
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Alaska does not have a residency requirement - 'the public' includes anyone. Inspection is distinct from copying and may not require fees.
rights_of_access.request_tips: Assert: 'Under Alaska Stat. § 40.25.110, I request to inspect [specific records] as all public records are open to public inspection unless prohibited by law.'

rights_of_access.description: Every person has a right to inspect a public record in the state, including records in electronic data processing applications, electronic audiotapes, videotapes, or other electronic or mechanical recordings, at reasonable times under reasonable conditions with supervision.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must be at reasonable times; custodian or designee may supervise; agency may impose reasonable conditions to protect record integrity
rights_of_access.applies_to: All public records in any format - paper, electronic, audio, video, or other mechanical recordings
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Alaska explicitly includes electronic records in inspection rights; supervision is permitted to protect records but cannot be used as pretext to deny access
rights_of_access.request_tips: Cite: 'Alaska Stat. § 40.25.120(a) grants me the right to inspect [records type] including electronic formats, at reasonable times under your supervision.'

rights_of_access.description: Public records in electronic form are available to the public if: (1) responsive records are identified after reasonable search, (2) records exist in electronic format, (3) agency can retrieve electronically with reasonable effort, and (4) providing records doesn't violate licensing/IP rights.
rights_of_access.conditions: Records must exist in electronic format; agency must be able to retrieve with reasonable effort; cannot violate contractual or intellectual property obligations
rights_of_access.applies_to: All public records maintained in electronic form
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Alaska requires agencies to provide electronic records when they exist electronically, preventing agencies from forcing paper-only access to electronic records
rights_of_access.request_tips: Request: 'Under Alaska Stat. § 40.25.115, please provide these records in electronic format as they are maintained electronically by your agency.'

rights_of_access.description: Requesters may request specific electronic formats. Agencies must provide in requested format if records exist in that format or can be produced with reasonable effort. If not, agency must provide in format records are maintained in.
rights_of_access.conditions: Agency must accommodate requested format if reasonable; if not possible, must provide in native format; may charge actual cost of format conversion
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Agencies cannot refuse electronic requests by claiming format difficulties - they must provide either in requested format or native format
rights_of_access.request_tips: Specify format: 'Please provide in [Excel/CSV/PDF] under Alaska Stat. § 40.25.115(b). If not possible, provide in native electronic format per § 40.25.115(c).'

rights_of_access.description: An agency may not charge a fee for the first two person-hours spent searching for or copying public records requested by the same person in a calendar month. This ensures small requests are free.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies to first 2 person-hours per requester per calendar month; covers both search and copy time; only executive branch agencies subject to this regulation
rights_of_access.applies_to: Requests to Alaska executive branch agencies
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: This is a significant requester protection - first 2 hours of work are always free each month, preventing cost from being barrier for most requests
rights_of_access.request_tips: Cite protection: 'Under 2 AAC 96.400(a), you may not charge for the first two person-hours of search and copy time for my requests this calendar month.'

rights_of_access.description: An agency may charge a fee of 25 cents per page for copying public records if the agency makes the copies. This caps the maximum per-page fee at a reasonable rate.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies when agency makes copies; if requester makes copies using agency equipment, reasonable equipment use fee may be charged instead
rights_of_access.applies_to: Paper copies made by Alaska executive branch agencies
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: 25¢/page cap prevents excessive copying fees from becoming access barrier; significantly lower than some other states
rights_of_access.request_tips: Challenge excessive fees: '2 AAC 96.400(c) caps copy fees at 25¢ per page when the agency makes copies. Please adjust your fee estimate.'

rights_of_access.subcategory: Actual Cost Standard for Electronic Records
rights_of_access.description: An agency may charge a reasonable fee for providing electronic records, not to exceed the agency's actual cost of providing the electronic records or services. Electronic delivery should be low-cost or free.
rights_of_access.conditions: Fee must be reasonable; cannot exceed actual cost; covers cost of electronic production and delivery only
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Email delivery of electronic records should typically be free or minimal cost; agencies cannot charge inflated fees for electronic delivery
rights_of_access.request_tips: For electronic delivery: 'Alaska Stat. § 40.25.115(e) limits electronic records fees to actual cost. Please provide fee breakdown showing only actual electronic production costs.'

rights_of_access.description: If searching for and copying records will exceed two person-hours in a calendar month, agency may charge actual personnel costs for time spent. However, agency must require payment before beginning the search if it will exceed 2 hours.
rights_of_access.conditions: Only applies after first 2 free hours exhausted; agency may require advance payment; must charge actual personnel costs only (no markup)
rights_of_access.applies_to: Time-intensive requests to Alaska executive branch agencies exceeding 2 person-hours
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Agencies must provide estimate and require payment before starting work on large requests; prevents surprise bills but also ensures requester knows costs upfront
rights_of_access.request_tips: For large requests, ask: 'Under 2 AAC 96.400(b), please provide cost estimate for search and copy time exceeding 2 hours before beginning work.'

rights_of_access.description: An agency shall respond to a request within 10 working days after receiving the request. This ensures timely initial response to public records requests.
rights_of_access.conditions: 10 working days = Monday-Friday excluding state holidays; applies to executive branch agencies; agency may extend with proper notice
rights_of_access.applies_to: Requests to Alaska executive branch agencies
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Working days, not calendar days - approximately 2 weeks. Response must be substantive (provide records, explain delay, or deny with justification)
rights_of_access.request_tips: Cite deadline: '2 AAC 96.325(a) requires a response within 10 working days of receipt. Please confirm receipt and expected response date.'

rights_of_access.description: If an agency cannot respond completely within 10 working days, the agency may extend the time for response by up to 10 additional working days by sending written notice within the original 10-day period. The notice must explain the reason for the extension.
rights_of_access.conditions: Extension limited to 10 additional working days (total 20 working days); must provide written notice within original 10-day period; must explain reason for extension
rights_of_access.applies_to: Complex or voluminous requests to Alaska executive branch agencies
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Total maximum 20 working days (~4 weeks) with extension; agency must justify extension in writing within first 10 days
rights_of_access.request_tips: If extended, verify: 'Your extension under 2 AAC 96.325(b) must be in writing, explain the reason, and not exceed 10 additional working days. Please confirm completion date.'

rights_of_access.description: If an agency cannot complete its response within the initial 10-working-day period and the 10-working-day extension, the agency may request that the requester agree to another extension. Requester consent is required.
rights_of_access.conditions: Requires requester agreement; no specified limit on length; should be reasonable and negotiated with requester
rights_of_access.applies_to: Extremely complex or voluminous requests requiring more than 20 working days
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Requester controls whether to grant further extensions; requester can refuse and treat delay as denial, providing grounds for appeal
rights_of_access.request_tips: If agency requests further extension: 'Under 2 AAC 96.325(c), further extensions require my agreement. Please explain why additional time is necessary.'

rights_of_access.description: An agency may determine a record is confidential only if the need for confidentiality outweighs the public interest in disclosure. Agency must balance factors including public participation, government accountability, revealing waste/fraud, privacy, and public safety.
rights_of_access.conditions: Agency has burden to prove confidentiality outweighs disclosure; must consider 8 specific factors listed in statute; presumption favors disclosure
rights_of_access.applies_to: All discretionary confidentiality determinations by Alaska agencies
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: This creates a strong presumption of openness - agencies cannot withhold records without affirmatively proving confidentiality need outweighs public interest
rights_of_access.request_tips: Challenge withholdings: 'Alaska Stat. § 40.25.122(a) requires you to prove confidentiality need outweighs public interest. Please explain your balancing analysis for each withheld record.'

rights_of_access.description: If an agency determines under AS 40.25.122(a) that a public record or information in a record is confidential, the agency shall segregate the confidential record or information and make available for inspection any part of the record that is not confidential.
rights_of_access.conditions: Applies when any portion of record contains confidential information; agency must separate exempt from non-exempt; must produce non-exempt portions
rights_of_access.applies_to: Records containing both confidential and non-confidential information
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Agencies cannot withhold entire documents when only portions are confidential; must perform redaction analysis and produce segregable portions
rights_of_access.request_tips: Assert: 'Alaska Stat. § 40.25.122(b) requires you to segregate any confidential information and provide all non-confidential portions. Please produce redacted records with only confidential portions withheld.'

rights_of_access.description: A person denied the right to inspect or copy a public record may apply to the superior court for an order directing that the record be made available. Application must be made within 180 days of the denial.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must file within 180 days of denial; court will hear matter promptly; agency has burden to prove record is exempt
rights_of_access.applies_to: Denials of public records requests in Alaska
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Burden shifts to agency in court - agency must prove by preponderance of evidence that record is exempt from inspection
rights_of_access.request_tips: If denied, note right: 'Alaska Stat. § 40.25.125 grants me the right to seek judicial review within 180 days. I am considering exercising this right if you do not provide the requested records.'

rights_of_access.description: If the court orders that the public record be made available for inspection or copying, the court may award court costs and reasonable attorney fees to the applicant. This incentivizes compliance and makes legal challenges financially feasible.
rights_of_access.conditions: Court has discretion to award fees; typically awarded when agency denial was improper; covers court costs and attorney fees
rights_of_access.applies_to: Successful judicial challenges to records denials
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Fee-shifting provision makes it financially viable to challenge improper denials, as successful requesters can recover legal costs
rights_of_access.request_tips: When considering litigation: 'Alaska Stat. § 40.25.125(c) provides for attorney fee recovery if I prevail in court. This makes pursuing judicial review financially feasible.'

rights_of_access.description: A person may appeal a final administrative order of a public agency by filing a notice of appeal in the superior court within 30 days after receiving notice of the final administrative order.
rights_of_access.conditions: Must exhaust administrative remedies first (if agency has administrative appeal process); file within 30 days of final administrative order; heard under Rules of Appellate Procedure
rights_of_access.applies_to: Final administrative orders on public records requests
rights_of_access.implementation_notes: Some agencies have internal administrative appeal processes that must be exhausted before judicial review; check agency regulations for administrative appeal procedures
rights_of_access.request_tips: After final administrative denial: 'Under Alaska Stat. § 40.25.124, I have 30 days to appeal this final administrative order to superior court. Please confirm this is your final administrative determination.'
